security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing markdown files with Seaborn visualization tutorials and examples. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access. Safe for publication.

content.value_statement: Creating publication-quality statistical graphics requires specialized knowledge of visualization libraries. Seaborn provides a Python library for generating informative and attractive visualizations with minimal code. Use this skill to explore datasets, discover patterns, and communicate findings through professional charts.
actual_capabilities: Create scatter plots with automatic semantic mappings for hue, size, and style
Build distribution visualizations including histograms, KDE plots, and ECDFs
Design categorical comparisons with box plots, violin plots, and bar charts
Generate correlation heatmaps and hierarchically clustered heatmaps
Create multi-panel figures with FacetGrid for faceted visualizations
Produce regression plots with confidence intervals and polynomial fits
limitations: Requires Python environment with Seaborn and matplotlib installed
Cannot perform statistical calculations beyond visualization helpers
Interactive features limited to Jupyter notebook environments
Does not generate animated or 3D visualizations

output_examples.input: Show the distribution of tips by day with a violin plot
output: A violin plot showing the probability density of tip amounts
Box plot statistics (median, quartiles) displayed inside each violin
Points jittered around the violins showing individual observations
Different colors for each day of the week

best_practices: Use DataFrames with named columns instead of arrays to get automatic axis labels
Choose plot type based on variable types: scatter for continuous x continuous, violin for categorical x continuous
Use semantic mappings (hue, size, style) to encode multiple variables instead of creating separate plots
Control statistical estimation by setting estimator, errorbar, and confidence interval parameters
anti_patterns: Using more than 6-8 colors in a single plot makes categories indistinguishable
Overlapping points without jitter or swarm layout hides data density and individual observations
Creating overly complex multi-panel figures that require extensive scrolling or zooming to understand

faq.question: Which Python version does Seaborn support?
faq.answer: Seaborn 0.12+ requires Python 3.9 or later. Earlier versions support Python 3.7+.

faq.question: What plot types are available in Seaborn?
faq.answer: Seaborn supports scatter, line, bar, box, violin, histogram, KDE, ECDF, heatmap, regression, and distribution plots.

faq.question: Can Seaborn handle large datasets?
faq.answer: Seaborn works with large datasets but consider using hexbin plots or sampling for millions of points to maintain performance.

faq.question: How does Seaborn integrate with other tools?
faq.answer: Seaborn builds on matplotlib for rendering and pandas for data structures. It works with Jupyter notebooks and exports to all matplotlib-supported formats.

faq.question: Is Seaborn safe for sensitive data?
faq.answer: Seaborn only visualizes data you provide locally. No data is sent to external servers. Always ensure your data handling complies with privacy requirements.

faq.question: How does Seaborn compare to Plotly or Altair?
faq.answer: Seaborn produces static publication-quality figures. Plotly offers interactivity. Altair provides a declarative grammar similar to Seaborn's objects interface.
